abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project are as
            follows: the project outcome is unsatisfactory, the
            project's sustainability is unlikely, the institutional
            development impact is modest, and the Bank and Borrower
            performance are both satisfactory overall. Given the
            pioneering nature of the project design, notably with regard
            to the processes associated with the identification,
            appraisal and financing of infrastructure projects, there
            are substantive lessons learned. To attempt to capture the
            full value of these lessons, an additional Annex 11 has been
            created to detail these findings in full, including
            suggested remedies. The lessons are of particular relevance
            for future initiatives including implementation agencies
            acting as financing intermediaries. The summary lessons
            learned are as follows: 1) The creation of an infrastructure
            fund was not a sufficient catalyst to increase private
            sector investment in infrastructure as financing was not the
            binding constraint. 2) The project was hampered throughout
            by governance and control issues which emanated from the
            attempt to establish a body which was at the same time
            independent of government and transparent in its actions but
            ultimately responsible for public funds. While the rationale
            was a perceived need to be flexible but somehow maintain
            transparency, this rather resulted in a lack of clarity of
            function. 3) The Private Sector Infrastructure Development
            Company (PSIDC) was perceived to be a government agency by
            infrastructure promoters and by financial sector
            participants and was treated as such. 4) During project
            design, the core team did not include all the relevant skill
            groups. 5) The project design was lacking relative to the
            complexity of the core elements of the task relating to
            project finance and lending operations. 6) The range of
            financial products available to PSIDC was too limited and
            there is no linkage between the riskiness of projects and
            the price or allocation of credit. 7) The aim of the PSIDC
            playing the role of "lender of last resort"
            appeared unnatural to private sector practitioners more
            inclined to try to build an institution, grow business and
            secure tenure. 8) The transitory nature of the project
            design did not jibe well with the long dated nature of the
            sub-loans or with the structure of PSIDC as a limited
            liability company with indefinite life. The description of
            agreed objectives and processes for the implementation of
            the "Sunset Clause" in the project documentation
            was too vague. 9) The implementing agency responsible for
            the technical assistance component should have been distinct
            to that for the lending component. 10) The project failed to
            support capital market development and particularly missed
            the opportunity to promote local currency financing. 11) The
            procurement requirements of the IDA credit appeared
            unacceptable to some private sector contractors and
            potential infrastructure providers were reportedly dissuaded
            from using the PSIDC facility.
